intro: Sagenia polymorpha, commonly known as the common sagina, is a low-growing perennial plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its prostrate growth habit and small, clustered flowers. The plant produces white or pinkish flowers that bloom in early spring, often preceding the leaves. Its foliage consists of small, fleshy, ovate leaves that are typically covered in a fine layer of white hair. Sagenia polymorpha is often found in moist, shaded areas such as woodlands and stream banks.
